article.headline: Unbeaten Mountaineers deal Tigers first loss
article.linkText: Mountaineers wade through Bayou, tame Tigers
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- West Virginia's shooters gave LSU little chance to show off its transition game. Tyrone Sally's 22 points led the Mountaineers, who shot 60 percent on Saturday to hand LSU its first loss of the season, 84-69. West Virginia also snapped LSU's streak of 56 home victories against teams from outside the Southeastern Conference. "The big thing is that if you make shots against them, then they can't just get into that dangerous transition game," WVU coach John Beilein said. "Thank goodness we made a lot of shots." LSU (3-1) used an 11-2 run late in the second half to get as close as 66-62, but the Mountaineers (3-0) responded by scoring the next 10 points and held a comfortable lead over the last four minutes. Patrick Beilein scored 18 points on six 3-pointers for West Virginia, while Kevin Pittsnogle added 13 points, Mike Gansey 12 and Johannes Herber 10. "I was in one of those zones where it is tough for me to miss," the younger Beilein said. "I was just feeling it, and the rim just looked so big. You just can't describe the feeling." Beilein also was an important part of a West Virginia defense that held the Tigers to 38.6 percent shooting. "We did a great job mixing up our zones and going back to man-to-man," Patrick Beilein said. "I think we had them a little confused." Tac Minor led LSU with a career-high 17 points. Brandon Bass had 15 points and nine rebounds, while Darrel Mitchell added 14 points. With both teams trading baskets for the first 10 minutes of the game, a jumper from Pittsnogle gave the Mountaineers a 19-17 lead with 11:53 remaining in the first half. A 10-0 West Virginia run pushed the Mountaineers' lead to 36-24 with under seven minutes to go in the first half. After that, the Tigers struggled to stay with West Virginia. LSU coach John Brady had little criticism of his team's performance on the offensive end. "Sixty-nine points is fine," Brady said. "I've had a lot of teams score 70 points in a game and do well. The biggest problem with our team today was defensively we couldn't stop them. They scored on us when they wanted to, how they wanted to. They took us off the dribble, made shots over us and I think that was the game."
